questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, weakness, and difficulty feeding. He was delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman. He is not able to sit upright on his own. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg, pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 50/min. His tongue protrudes beyond the teeth. Neck veins are distended. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows profound weakness in proximal and distal muscles of the upper and lower extremities. He has 2+ reflexes bilaterally. A chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly. Serum glucose is 95 mg/dL. Which of the following is the enzyme most likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase is deficient in McArdle disease (i.e., GSD-V). Without this enzyme, glycogen metabolism is disrupted and glycogen abnormally accumulates in muscle cells. The resulting muscle cell lysis leads to elevated serum creatine kinase and myoglobin. Patients with McArdle disease usually present during adolescence or early adulthood and classically report episodes of muscle pain, cramps, poor endurance, and brown urine (myoglobinuria) after aerobic exercise. Because only skeletal muscle is affected, the cardiac muscle is spared and heart failure is not a common feature, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A lack of very-long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase causes very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (VLCAD deficiency). VLCAD deficiency affects the degradation of very-long-chain fatty acids within the peroxisomes. While patients with VLCAD can also present with hepatomegaly, generalized hypotonia, and signs of heart failure (due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) during infancy or early childhood, one of the hallmarks of VLCAD is hypoglycemia associated with fasting or illness. This patient is normoglycemic, making the diagnosis unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

A defect in lysosomal acid maltase (also referred to as lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase) is responsible for Pompe disease (i.e., GSD-II). Without this enzyme, the conversion of glycogen to glucose in the lysosome cannot be completed and glycogen buildup becomes toxic to numerous cells, predominantly skeletal and cardiac muscle cells. Notably, the condition does not manifest with hypoglycemia or metabolic acidosis because glycolysis and gluconeogenesis do not depend on lysosomal glycogenolysis.

This patient has infantile-onset Pompe disease, which is the most severe form of this condition. It is characterized by rapidly progressing symptoms and has an average life expectancy of one year if left untreated. Enzyme replacement therapy (e.g., with recombinant human acid alpha-glucosidase) should be initiated as soon as possible in all patients with infantile-onset Pompe disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease (i.e., GSD-I). In cells missing this enzyme, the final step in the conversion of glycogen to glucose cannot occur. Consequently, a major hallmark of the deficiency is hypoglycemia due to an inability to generate and release glucose (especially in hepatocytes). Other common findings include failure to thrive with short stature and thin extremities, as well as pronounced cheeks (“doll-like facies”). While von Gierke disease also manifests with hepatomegaly in infants, signs of heart failure, macroglossia, and normoglycemia suggest another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Glycogen debranching enzyme is deficient in Cori disease (i.e., GSD-III). Without this enzyme, the hydrolysis of glycogen to glucose cannot be completed. A hallmark of this condition is hypoglycemia (due to a failure of hepatic glucose generation and release). Cori disease can also cause hepatomegaly, muscle hypotonia, and, as the disease progresses, cardiomyopathy. However, in this infant, macroglossia, severe cardiomyopathy, and normoglycemia suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: This child presents with global muscle hypotonia, features of heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, jugular venous distention, cardiomegaly), macroglossia, and normal serum glucose, all of which suggest Pompe disease, a glycogen storage disease (GSD).

questions.text:
A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after having a seizure. He has had multiple seizures during the past week. His mother also notes that he has become lethargic and has had a weak cry for the past month. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), respirations are 50/min, and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin; there is no splenomegaly. Serum studies show:


Na+

137 mEq/L


Cl-

103 mEq/L


K+

3.9 mEq/L


Glucose
32 mg/dL


Calcium
9.6 mg/dL


Total cholesterol
290 mg/dL


Triglycerides
260 mg/dL


Lactate

4.2 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2 mEq/L)


A deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of the glycogen branching enzyme results in Andersen disease (type IV GSD), which may manifest with hepatomegaly. However, some degree of splenomegaly would also be evident, and hypoglycemia does not occur in Andersen disease until liver failure with associated cirrhosis and ascites develops. Hyperlipidemia and increased lactate levels are not typically seen in patients with Andersen disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency results in classic galactosemia, which can manifest with failure to thrive, lethargy, and hepatomegaly. However, patients would typically also have other features such as vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, and cataracts.

C) INCORRECT:

Fructokinase deficiency results in a benign condition called essential fructosuria, which is essentially asymptomatic.

A disorder of fructose metabolism known as hereditary fructose intolerance might manifest with hepatomegaly and severe hypoglycemia leading to seizures. However, this disorder is caused by a deficiency of aldolase B and usually manifests after the age of 6 months, when infants are weaned and given food containing sucrose.

D) CORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is the underlying cause of von Gierke disease (type a), which typically manifests with failure to thrive, lethargy, hepatomegaly, severe fasting hypoglycemia (causing hypoglycemic seizures), hyperlipidemia, and lactic acidosis. Further characteristic findings include hyperuricemia and facial fat deposition (sometimes referred to as a “doll-like” face). Like other GSDs, von Gierke disease can be managed effectively with diet modifications (e.g., uncooked corn starch, glucose preparations), which aim to prevent hypoglycemia and muscle symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase results in Pompe disease (type II GSD), which may manifest during infancy with lethargy and hepatomegaly. However, infantile Pompe disease characteristically results in generalized hypotonia, macroglossia, and rapidly progressive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which typically causes respiratory distress and clinical features of cardiomegaly (e.g., a displaced, forceful apex beat). Increased lactate levels, hyperlipidemia, and hypoglycemia are not typically seen in patients with Pompe disease.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with one of the most common glycogen storage disorders (GSDs).

questions.text: A 6-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of her eyes and body, vomiting, and poor feeding for 3 days. She has had diarrhea for the past 2 days. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and the antenatal period was uncomplicated. She appears lethargic. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Bilateral cataracts are present. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin; there is no splenomegaly. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Serum glucose concentration is 37 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent long-term complications of this illness?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phototherapy is indicated to treat severe neonatal jaundice. Although phototherapy might help prevent kernicterus in neonates with severe hyperbilirubinemia, it does not address the underlying condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent carbohydrate feeds are indicated in patients with certain glycogen storage diseases such as von Gierke disease, which may manifest with severe hypoglycemia, lethargy, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly. Intermittent diarrhea may also occur in some patients. However, patients would have other features such as a doll-like face and abdominal distention. Bilateral cataracts and vomiting are not features of von Gierke disease.

C) CORRECT:

The most common form of galactosemia is galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency, which leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol. The severe manifestations of galactosemia are a direct result of these toxic metabolites. Infantile cataracts are caused by the accumulation of galactitol in the eye lens. Newborns typically become symptomatic after the initiation of breastfeeding or formula feeding. The condition can be diagnosed by the presence of increased levels of galactose in the urine or increased levels of galactose-1-phosphate in the blood. Patients with classic galactosemia must avoid food containing lactose (e.g., cow's milk, breast milk).

D) INCORRECT:

Thiamine therapy is indicated for patients with maple syrup urine disease, which may manifest with feeding difficulty, lethargy, vomiting, and hypoglycemia. Although bouts of hypotonia may occur, patients are usually hypertonic. Also, a characteristic maple syrup odor would be present because leucine, isoleucine, and valine, as well as their ketoacids, are excreted in the urine, fecal excretions, and cerumen. Maple syrup urine disease does not manifest hepatomegaly and bilateral cataracts.

E) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine therapy is indicated for neonates with congenital hypothyroidism, which may result in hypotonia, lethargy, feeding difficulties, and prolonged icterus. However, congenital hypothyroidism would manifest with other features such as dry skin, constipation, widely open fontanelles, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and/or hypothermia. Congenital hypothyroidism does not manifest with hepatomegaly, vomiting, or bilateral cataracts.
questions.hint: This newborn presents with jaundice, diarrhea, cataracts, hepatomegaly, and hypoglycemia, all of which suggest galactosemia.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician because of severe muscle cramps and pain for 3 months. He first noticed these symptoms while attending tryouts for the high school football team. Since then, he becomes easily fatigued and has severe muscle pain and swelling after 10 minutes of playing. However, after a brief period of rest, the symptoms improve, and he is able to return to the game. Two days ago, he had an episode of reddish-brown urine after playing football. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. Serum creatine kinase concentration is 333 U/L. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
2+


Protein
negative


Glucose
negative


RBC
negative


WBC
1–2/hpf


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: CTG repeat in the DMPK gene

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCAD deficiency) may manifest with exercise intolerance and elevated serum creatinine kinase due to muscle catabolism. However, this weakness would develop with more prolonged exercise, not within a few minutes. Additionally, patients with MCAD deficiency would not experience the rapid symptom improvement seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid hormone deficiency causes hypothyroidism, which can manifest with myopathy as seen in this patient. However, these symptoms would be present at rest rather than improve with rest as seen in this patient. Additionally, hypothyroidism would likely manifest with other general symptoms such as fatigue, cold intolerance, cold skin, weight gain, constipation, delayed reflexes, or myxedema. Finally, hypothyroidism is uncommon in otherwise healthy teenage boys (5–8 times more common in women).

C) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the dystrophin gene can result in Duchenne muscular dystrophy or Becker muscular dystrophy, depending on the type of mutation, and can result in myalgias and elevated creatine kinase. However, both of these conditions show a progressive clinical course and are characterized by symptoms that occur both at rest and during exercise. In addition, symptoms do not improve with rest, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease) is a glycogen storage disease that manifests with myalgias, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria, and early fatigue from exercise due to the inability to break down glycogen for use as energy in muscle tissues. Treatment often involves aerobic exercise programs and nutritional supplementation, although evidence of benefit is limited.

E) INCORRECT:

Lysosomal acid maltase deficiency (Pompe disease) is a glycogen storage disease that can manifest with myopathy and exercise intolerance, as seen in this patient. However, Pompe disease is usually diagnosed in infants and young children who present with failure to thrive along with myopathy and, sometimes, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and/or macroglossia. Moreover, the rapid improvement of this patient's symptoms following rest is characteristic of another disease. Although there is a late-onset form of Pompe disease that develops in adolescents and young adults, another diagnosis is much more likely in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

CTG repeats in the DMPK gene cause myotonic dystrophy. While myotonic dystrophy can be associated with muscle pain and weakness, it causes symptoms at rest and is associated with delayed muscle relaxation following contraction (myotonia). Additionally, myotonic dystrophy is associated with arrhythmias, cataracts, testicular atrophy, and insulin resistance.
questions.hint: This individual has severe muscle cramps and pain after physical activity along with myoglobinuria (red-brown urine with positive blood but no RBCs on urinalysis) and elevated serum creatine kinase. These features along with the second wind phenomenon (ability to resume physical activity after a break) are consistent with McArdle disease.

questions.text: A 7-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of lethargy, vomiting, poor feeding, and diarrhea for 4 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral cataracts and icterus are present. Examination shows jaundice of the skin, and the liver is palpated 5-cm below the right costal margin. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Serum glucose concentration is 40 mg/dL. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sphingomyelin accumulates in Niemann-Pick disease. Although eye involvement and hepatomegaly are clinical features of Niemann-Pick disease, the eye manifestation is cherry-red spot on the macula rather than cataracts. In addition, Niemann-Pick disease is uncommon in the first week of life; instead, clinical manifestations usually start to develop in early childhood, and hypoglycemia is not expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Uric acid accumulates in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Clinical features include developmental delay, dystonia, spasticity, gouty arthritis, urate nephropathy, and self-injurious behavior, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease that primarily affects males, and bilateral cataracts and hypoglycemia are not expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Branched-chain amino acids accumulate in maple syrup urine disease. Although lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and hypotonia are clinical features of maple syrup urine disease, this newborn lacks the characteristic maple syrup odor in the urine. In addition, bilateral cataracts are not expected in maple syrup urine disease.

D) CORRECT:

The most common form of galactosemia is galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) deficiency (classic galactosemia). Infantile cataracts are caused by accumulation of galactitol in the eye lens. Hypoglycemia develops because galactose cannot be used for glycolysis, and in breastfeeding newborns, lactose (broken down into glucose and galactose) is the main source of nutrition. If galactosemia is left untreated, complications such as cirrhosis, renal failure, hypogonadism, seizures, and brain damage can occur. Another milder form of galactosemia is galactokinase deficiency, which also causes infantile cataracts but does not cause damage to other organs such as the liver damage in this patient. Since these manifestations can be prevented by avoiding milk products, guidelines in the US state that all newborns should be screened for galactosemia.

Neonates with classic galactosemia are at increased risk of developing sepsis due to E. coli.
Image Description:

Illustration of the galactose metabolism in the liver

Galactose is added to the glucose metabolism by activating it through galactokinase at the C1 atom via phosphorylation. A UDP molecule is then transferred to the resulting galactose-1-phosphate. This molecule is provided by UDP-glucose and transferred through Gal-1-P uridylyltransferase; in this process, glucose-1-phosphate is released that can be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and introduced to the glycolysis. Next, UDP-glucose 4-epimerase can transfer UDP-galactosis to the UDP-glucose; then, it can be either directly used for the glycosynthesis or react with another molecule to galactose 1-phosphate.

E) INCORRECT:

Limit dextrins accumulate in Cori disease. Although lethargy, poor feeding, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly are clinical features of cori disease, bilateral cataracts are not expected. In addition, newborns affected with cori disease are usually healthy during the first few months of life and hypoglycemia is uncommon.
questions.hint: This newborn has diarrhea, cataracts, jaundice/icterus, and hepatomegaly with hypoglycemia, which are indicative of classic galactosemia.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after having a generalized seizure. His mother reports that he has become lethargic and has had a weak cry for the past 3 weeks. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Examination shows prominent cheeks and a distended, non-tender abdomen. The liver is palpated 5 cm below the right costal margin and there are palpable masses in both flanks. His serum glucose is 37 mg/dL, cholesterol is 253 mg/dL, uric acid is 9.5 mg/dL, and lactate is 4.3 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2). An enzyme responsible for which of the following reactions is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The deficient enzyme in von Gierke disease is glucose-6-phosphatase, which catalyzes the final steps of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Loss of this enzyme means the liver can no longer release glucose from its abundant glycogen stores, and it loses the ability to control blood sugar. Patients therefore present early in life (3–6 months) with severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, severe hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.

Treatment is focused on preventing hypoglycemia through frequent glucose supplementation (oral cornstarch), a diet of complex carbohydrates, and avoidance of other sugars that require this enzyme for metabolism into glucose (lactose, fructose, galactose, sucrose).

B) INCORRECT:

The enzyme that catalyzes the addition of individual UDP-glucose molecules to the growing glycogen polymer is glycogen synthase. Mutations in this gene result in a rare form of glycogen storage disease, which may also lead to fasting hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. However, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, hyperuricemia, and doll-like facies would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

The enzyme responsible for the addition of glucose polymer branches to a glycogen backbone through α(1,6) bonds is called branching enzyme. Defects in this gene result in a rare glycogen storage disorder (Andersen disease), which could also present with hepatomegaly and failure to thrive. However, the patient's other symptoms would not be expected in this type of glycogen storage disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Glycogen phosphorylase is the enzyme responsible for releasing glucose-1-phosphate molecules from the branches of glycogen polymers. In McArdle disease, the skeletal muscle version of this enzyme (myophosphorylase) is deficient, which leads to increased glycogen stores in the skeletal muscle. However, symptoms typically manifest in adolescence, not in infancy, and include painful muscle cramps, exercise intolerance (with possible second wind phenomenon), rhabdomyolysis, and myoglobinuria, none of which are present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The enzyme responsible for cleaving the final glucose molecules from an individual glycogen branch is called α-1,6-glucosidase, which is part of the function of the debranching enzyme. Deficiency in the debranching enzyme results in Cori disease, which can also manifest with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, fasting hypoglycemia, and hyperlipidemia. Because gluconeogenesis and some level of glycogenolysis remain intact in these patients, hypoglycemia is usually mild and lactic acidosis does not occur. Furthermore, hyperuricemia and renomegaly would not be expected in Cori disease.

F) INCORRECT:

The enzyme responsible for cleavage of glucose molecules from the branches of glycogen inside the lysosome is called lysosomal acid maltase. Defects in this gene result in Pompe disease, which classically manifests around this patient's age with failure to thrive. However, other symptoms would also be expected, e.g., hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, proximal myopathy, exercise intolerance, and macroglossia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with severe hypoglycemia, which has likely caused his seizure. He also has hepatomegaly, renomegaly (palpable flank masses), hypercholesterolemia, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis, which should raise suspicion for von Gierke disease. The prominent cheeks (doll-like facies) are likely due to facial fat deposition, which is typical of this condition.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of muscle weakness and cramps for 5 months. He becomes easily fatigued and has severe muscle pain and swelling after 15 minutes of playing basketball with his friends. The symptoms improve after a brief period of rest. After playing, he sometimes also has episodes of reddish-brown urine. There is no family history of serious illness. Serum creatine kinase concentration is 950 U/L. Urinalysis shows:


Blood
2+


Protein
negative


Glucose
negative


RBC
negative


WBC
1–2/hpf


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: CTG repeat in the DMPK gene
Low levels of triiodothyronine and thyroxine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CTG repeats in the DMPK gene cause myotonic dystrophy. While myotonic dystrophy can be associated with muscle pain and weakness as in this patient, it causes symptoms at rest and is associated with delayed muscle relaxation following contraction (myotonia). Additionally, myotonic dystrophy is associated with arrhythmias, cataracts, testicular atrophy, and insulin resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

Low thyroid hormone levels cause hypothyroidism, which can present with myopathy as seen in this patient. However, these symptoms would be present at rest rather than improve with rest. Additionally, hypothyroidism would likely present with other general symptoms such as fatigue, cold intolerance, cold skin, weight gain, constipation, delayed reflexes, or myxedema. Finally, hypothyroidism is uncommon in otherwise healthy teenage boys (5–8 times more common in women).

C) INCORRECT:

Dystrophin gene mutations cause Duchenne muscular dystrophy or Becker muscular dystrophy, depending on the type of mutation. While these disorders can result in myalgias and elevated creatine kinase, as in this patient, they are usually progressive conditions that would demonstrate symptoms both at rest and with exercise. Additionally, symptoms in dystrophinopathies would not improve so significantly with rest. Lastly, Duchenne muscular dystrophy typically presents before age 5 and usually leads to ambulatory inability before age 13.

D) INCORRECT:

Lysosomal acid maltase deficiency (Pompe disease) is a glycogen storage disease that can present with myopathy and exercise intolerance as in this patient. However, Pompe disease is usually diagnosed in infants and young children who present with failure to thrive along with myopathy and, sometimes, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and/or macroglossia. Moreover, the rapid improvement of this patient's symptoms following rest is characteristic of another disease.

E) INCORRECT:

MCAD deficiency can present with exercise intolerance and elevated serum creatinine kinase due to muscle catabolism. However, this weakness would develop with more prolonged exercise, not within a few minutes. Additionally, patients with MCAD deficiency would not experience the rapid symptom improvement seen in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Myophosphorylase deficiency (McArdle's disease) is a glycogen storage disease that presents with myalgias, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria, and early fatigue from exercise due to inability to break down glycogen for use as energy in muscle tissues. Many patients experience the second wind phenomenon, in which symptoms improve after a brief period of rest. A hallmark of McArdle's disease is a flat venous lactate curve with exaggerated elevations in blood ammonia during exercise. Treatment often involves aerobic exercise programs and nutritional supplementation, although evidence of benefit is limited.
questions.hint: This patient's muscle cramps and pain after physical activity, second wind phenomenon, myoglobinuria (red-brown urine with positive blood but no RBCs), elevated serum creatine kinase are indicative of McArdle's disease.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of recurrent vomiting and yellowing of his eyes. The mother says that he has been eating poorly since she started weaning him off of breast milk 5 days ago. At this time, mashed vegetables and fruits were added to his diet. Examination shows scleral jaundice and dry mucous membranes. The tip of the liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin. His serum glucose concentration is 47 mg/dL, serum alanine aminotransferase is 55 U/L, and serum aspartate aminotransferase is 66 U/L. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactokinase deficiency develops during infancy while breastfeeding, since galactose is present in breast milk. This patient's age is consistent with this condition, but it does not manifest during weaning. Galactokinase deficiency cause cataracts in early infancy because of accumulation of galactitol in the lenses. It does not manifest with hypoglycemia and abnormal liver function tests, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of the glycogen debranching enzyme causes type III glycogen storage disease (Cori disease). It manifests with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, which are seen in this patient. However, it is not associated with weaning. It also causes generalized muscle weakness and/or cramps, hyperlipidemia, and fasting intolerance (mild hypoglycemia and ketosis), none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase causes classic galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism that results in hepatomegaly, jaundice, poor feeding, vomiting, and hypoglycemia, which are all seen in this patient. However, this condition manifests soon after birth, since galactose is present in breast milk and formula.

D) CORRECT:

Aldolase B deficiency causes hereditary fructose intolerance, which manifests with vomiting, poor feeding, hypoglycemia, jaundice, and hepatomegaly. Aldolase B normally catalyzes the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate to glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone phosphate. Symptoms manifest around the time of weaning, as food containing fructose and/or sucrose is added to the diet at that time. Treatment of this condition involves a lifelong fructose-free and sucrose-free diet.
Image Description:

(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, which manifests with asymptomatic accumulation of fructose, leading to excretion of fructose in urine. Essential fructosuria does not cause liver enlargement, low serum glucose, elevated liver enzymes, or jaundice.

F) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke disease), a glycogen storage disease, causes hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia in infants around 3–6 months of age, which would be consistent with this patient. However, weaning plays no role in this disease process, which also causes severe hyperlipidemia, failure to thrive, poor fasting tolerance with mild ketosis, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis.
questions.hint: Given this infant's liver enlargement, low serum glucose, elevated liver enzymes, and jaundice after the addition of new foods while weaning, he likely has hereditary fructose intolerance.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of poor feeding and irritability. She is at the 15th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Examination shows hypotonia and wasting of skeletal muscles. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is hepatomegaly. Her serum glucose is 61 mg/dL, creatine kinase is 100 U/L, and lactic acid is within the reference range. Urine ketone bodies are elevated. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to the development of McArdle disease. It presents during adolescence or early adulthood with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, weakness, myoglobinuria and elevated creatine kinase level. Although this patient has hypotonia, her early presentation, hepatomegaly, and hypoglycemia are inconsistent with McArdle disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Acid alpha-glucosidase (lysosomal acid maltase) deficiency causes Pompe disease, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by lysosomal glycogen-like inclusion bodies. It presents in the first 2 months of life with muscle weakness, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, respiratory distress, failure to thrive, and hearing loss. Although this patient has hypotonia and hepatomegaly, she does not have cardiac involvement, which is a cardinal feature of Pompe disease. Moreover, Pompe disease does not present with hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to the development of von Gierke disease, which presents with hepatomegaly and mild ketosis. However, other key clinical features of this disease, such as severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia, are absent in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher disease, a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by intracellular accumulation of glucocerebroside. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly, fractures, neurological symptoms, pancytopenia, and macrophages with crumpled paper-like inclusions (Gaucher cells). Despite having hepatomegaly, this patient lacks other presenting features of Gaucher disease.

E) CORRECT:

Cori disease is an autosomal recessive glycogen storage disorder resulting from a deficiency of glycogen debranching enzyme, which performs 2 functions as α-1,6-glucosidase and 4-α-D-glucanotransferase. It presents with hypotonia, muscle wasting, mild hypoglycemia, and ketosis, as observed in this patient.
questions.hint: This infant's combination of failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, muscle wasting, mild hypoglycemia, and ketosis indicates Cori disease.

questions.text: A 12-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. The parents started introducing solid foods to his diet around 6 months ago. The boy is still being breastfed intermittently. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 65th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows 3+ reducing substances. Compared to a healthy infant, giving this patient apple juice to drink will result in increased activity of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aldolase B activity is decreased (not increased) in patients with essential fructosuria. This enzyme relies on the product of fructokinase activity (fructose-1-phosphate) as a substrate. Due to decreased availability of this substrate, aldolase B is much less active.

B) INCORRECT:

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase aids in galactose metabolism (and is deficient in patients with classic galactosemia). It plays no role in the compensatory metabolism of essential fructosuria. Classic galactosemia would present with jaundice, vomiting, hepatosplenomegaly, infantile cataracts, and failure to thrive, none of which is present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease (not increase) in fructokinase activity due to enzyme deficiency is the characteristic feature of essential fructosuria.

D) INCORRECT:

α-1,6-glucosidase aids in glycogen metabolism (and is deficient in patients with Cori disease). It plays no role in the compensatory metabolism of essential fructosuria. Cori disease would manifest with generalized muscle weakness, cramps, hepatosplenomegaly, cirrhosis, fasting hypoglycemia, ketosis, and hyperlipidemia, none of which is present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with essential fructosuria have fructokinase deficiency and thus cannot convert fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Hexokinase (found in adipocytes and myocytes) becomes the primary enzyme responsible for fructose metabolism and converts it to fructose-6-phosphate, which can be used for glycolysis or converted to glucose-6-phosphate by glucose-6-phosphate isomerase. Fructose that is not converted by hexokinase is excreted in urine, which leads to the presence of reducing substances.
Image Description:

(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.
questions.hint: The finding of a reducing substance in the urine of a healthy, asymptomatic infant suggests a diagnosis of essential fructosuria.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He feels well. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and a standard electrolyte panel, are within normal limits. Urine dipstick is negative for glucose; a reducing substance test result of the urine is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate dietary recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Increase intake of ketogenic amino acids

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eliminating fructose and sucrose from the diet would be recommended in hereditary fructose intolerance, which is characterized by fructose-1-phosphate accumulation, phosphate depletion, and inhibition of glycolytic pathways. Although a reducing sugar (fructose) could be detected in the urine (as is the case in this patient), hereditary fructose intolerance would present in early childhood with severe hypoglycemia, vomiting, jaundice, bleeding, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreasing purine intake would be recommended in conditions associated with hyperuricemia (e.g., primary gout, renal failure, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, tumor lysis syndrome, von Gierke disease). This patient, however, is an asymptomatic adult.

C) CORRECT:

No treatment is required for patients with essential fructosuria, a benign disorder of fructose metabolism caused by the deficiency of fructokinase, which converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Although fructokinase deficiency can lead to detectable fructose in the blood and urine, the condition has no clinical consequences, as hexokinase shunts excess fructose back into the glycolytic pathway by converting fructose directly to fructose-6-phosphate.
Image Description:

(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Eliminating galactose and lactose from the diet would be recommended in galactosemia, which is characterized by the accumulation of galactose and galactitol. Although galactosemia can present with a reducing sugar (galactose) in the urine, as seen in this patient, it presents as soon as an infant starts feeding with infantile cataracts, jaundice, vomiting, hepatosplenomegaly, and failure to thrive.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing intake of ketogenic amino acids may delay the progression of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency, which is caused by a dysfunction of the citric acid cycle leading to lactate build-up. It manifests early in life with nonspecific symptoms like lethargy, poor feeding, tachypnea, neurodevelopmental delays, and lactic acidosis. This patient is, however, asymptomatic and does not have a history of consistent symptoms.
questions.hint: The patient has a reducing sugar in his urine which is not glucose. As he is asymptomatic and has an otherwise completely normal exam the sugar is most likely fructose, leading to the diagnosis of essential fructosuria.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of chronic fatigue and generalized weakness after exertion. His legs feel stiff after walking long distances and he has leg cramps after climbing stairs. His symptoms are always relieved by rest. Urine dipstick shows 3+ blood and urinalysis is negative for RBCs. Baseline venous lactate and serum ammonia levels are collected, after which a blood pressure cuff is attached to the upper right arm. The patient is asked to continuously pump his right arm with the cuff inflated and additional venous samples are collected at 2-minute intervals. Analysis of the venous blood samples shows that, over time, serum ammonia levels increase and venous lactate levels remain stable. A biopsy of the right gastrocnemius muscle will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An intrafascicular CD8+ lymphocytic infiltrate on biopsy is consistent with polymyositis. While polymyositis manifests with muscle weakness, which is seen in this patient, it is typically proximal and symmetrical in nature and is especially pronounced in the pelvic and shoulder girdles. Furthermore, cramps are uncommon, and the muscle weakness is not profoundly exacerbated by exertion, which is the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Endomysial fibrosis with absent dystrophin is seen in individuals with muscular dystrophies, such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Muscle fiber degeneration occurs secondary to altered dystrophin protein, which is caused by underlying dystrophin gene mutations. Complete impairment of dystrophin results in the disturbance of cellular signaling pathways, which promotes necrosis of these cells. The necrotic cells are subsequently replaced by connective and fatty tissue. While patients with a dystrophin gene mutation may present with muscle weakness, which is seen in this patient, DMD appears significantly early in life, with most affected individuals using a wheelchair by late childhood. Furthermore, classic features of DMD (e.g., Gower sign, calf pseudohypertrophy) are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Intermyofibrillar proliferation of mitochondria would appear on biopsy as ragged red fibers, which are characteristic of mitochondrial myopathies. While there are several forms of mitochondrial myopathies, patients typically present with exercise intolerance, which is seen here. However, the forearm exercise test finding of flat venous lactate curve despite rising ammonia levels is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits indicate an increased accumulation of glycogen in muscle cells, which is seen in McArdle disease. The accumulation of glycogen in muscle cells is caused by myophosphorylase deficiency, which is an enzyme necessary for the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. The inability to break down glycogen leads to generalized muscle weakness and exercise intolerance, which are both seen in this patient. Furthermore, this inability to release glucose leads to a lack of anaerobic glycolysis, preventing a normal rise in lactate during the forearm exercise test.

E) INCORRECT:

A perivascular CD4+ lymphocytic infiltrate on biopsy is consistent with dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy typically characterized by proximal and symmetrical muscle weakness (especially of the pelvic and shoulder girdles) with skin involvement (e.g., Gottron papules or heliotrope rash). These features are not seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms of generalized muscle weakness, myoglobinuria (positive blood but negative RBCs), and exercise intolerance suggest a myopathy. The forearm exercise test finding of a flat venous lactate curve despite rising ammonia levels is consistent with McArdle disease.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of developmental delay. His mother reports that he babbles and turns his attention to her when she calls his name but she is concerned because he has never smiled and does not seem to recognize her face. He is exclusively breastfed and at the 60th percentile for height and 85th percentile for weight. Ophthalmological examination shows a white reflex in both eyes and a failure to track the penlight. During the examination, he sits without support and grasps toys that are placed in his hand. A reducing substance test result of the urine is positive, and a glucose oxidase test result is negative. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following labeled reactions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The enzyme that breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose is lactase. Lactase deficiency results in lactase malabsorption, which can cause diarrhea, abdominal pain, and flatulence after the consumption of lactose-containing products. This infant's presentation is more consistent with galactosemia.

B) INCORRECT:

The enzyme that reduces galactose to galactitol is aldose reductase. A medical condition involving aldose reductase deficiency is not known to exist. Moreover, this infant's presentation is more consistent with galactosemia.

C) CORRECT:

The enzyme that activates galactose to galactose-1-phosphate is galactokinase (GALK). Congenital GALK deficiency leads to pathologically increased conversion of galactose to galactitol by aldose reductase and manifests with elevated blood galactose, galactosuria, and early-onset cataracts (due to accumulation of galactitol in the lens). Compared to the more common classic galactosemia, GALK deficiency is less severe and does not result in liver, kidney, or brain damage. Also, cognitive and motor development remains unaffected, as in this patient. Treatment includes a lifelong lactose-free and galactose-free diet.
Image Description:

Illustration of the galactose metabolism in the liver

Galactose is added to the glucose metabolism by activating it through galactokinase at the C1 atom via phosphorylation. A UDP molecule is then transferred to the resulting galactose-1-phosphate. This molecule is provided by UDP-glucose and transferred through Gal-1-P uridylyltransferase; in this process, glucose-1-phosphate is released that can be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and introduced to the glycolysis. Next, UDP-glucose 4-epimerase can transfer UDP-galactosis to the UDP-glucose; then, it can be either directly used for the glycosynthesis or react with another molecule to galactose 1-phosphate.

D) INCORRECT:

The enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of galactose-1-phosphate to UDP-galactose is galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). Congenital GALT deficiency leading to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate is the cause of classic galactosemia. Classic galactosemia manifests with galactosuria and bilateral cataracts, as seen here. However, patients usually show clinical features (e.g., jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive) in the early neonatal period after initiation of feedings that contain galactose (e.g., breast milk), which has not been reported here. This boy instead has achieved gross and fine motor, language, and growth milestones that are appropriate for his age, which is more consistent with a milder form of galactosemia.

E) INCORRECT:

The enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of UDP-galactose to UDP-glucose is UDP-glucose 4-epimerase (GALE). Congenital GALE deficiency leads to a very rare form of galactosemia, which can manifest with galactosuria and bilateral cataracts, as seen here. However, patients usually present with clinical features (e.g., jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, diarrhea, failure to thrive) in the early neonatal period after initiation of feedings that contain galactose (e.g., breast milk), which has not been reported here. This infant boy instead has achieved gross and fine motor, language, and growth milestones that are appropriate for his age, which is more consistent with a milder form of galactosemia.
questions.hint: A positive reducing substance urine test along with a negative glucose oxidase test indicates the presence of a sugar other than glucose in this infant's urine. In combination with signs and symptoms of bilateral cataract (no social smile, leukocoria, failure to track penlight), this raises concern for galactosemia.

questions.text:
A 12-day-old male infant is evaluated in an urgent care center for lethargy and poor feeding. He was born full term to a 30-year-old gravida 2, para 2 mother in a planned home delivery attended by a lay midwife. There were no complications during the pregnancy or delivery, although the patient did have significant jaundice after birth that required extended home phototherapy with a bilirubin blanket.
His parents report that they have had difficulty waking him for feedings since he was 3 days old. He has been exclusively breastfed and vomits after most feeds. He has yet not seen his pediatrician for his first outpatient visit. Newborn screening has not been obtained.
He is afebrile on examination, and blood and urine cultures are sent because of the poor feeding. Twelve hours later, the blood culture begins growing gram-negative rods, and the family is immediately sent to the emergency department (ED).
On examination in the ED, the patient is jaundiced with scleral icterus, and eye examination reveals bilateral white reflexes. The anterior fontanelle is full but not bulging. The liver is firm and palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin. A point-of-care glucose measurement is 35 mg/dL (50–90).
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
35,000
5000–21,000


Ammonia (μg/dL)
200
79–129


International normalized ratio
3.5
--


Partial thromboplastin time (seconds)
62
22.1–54.0


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
16
<1.2


Direct bilirubin (mg/dL)
8
<0.6


A glucose infusion is used to correct the hypoglycemia, and fresh frozen plasma is administered to address the coagulopathy. Repeat cultures, including a cerebrospinal fluid culture, are sent, and antibiotics are started immediately.
What is the definitive treatment for this patient?

choices.text: A strict feeding regimen of 90 mL (3 ounces) every 3 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Light therapy for jaundice should not be undertaken until a patient’s total and direct bilirubin levels are established. Therapy depends on the age of the patient and other risk factors. If the patient has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, phototherapy should be avoided because of the risk for bronze baby syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Feedings of at least 90 mL (3 ounces) every 3 hours are critical for many infants who have inborn errors of metabolism that feature hypoglycemia. However, in galactosemia, hypoglycemia is caused by the inability to use galactose as a fuel; providing a non-galactose-containing fuel source (soy formula) will completely prevent hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin K-deficient bleeding is an important cause of coagulopathy, especially in newborns born at home, and it usually manifests at 1 to 4 weeks of life. However, this patient has additional symptoms beyond coagulopathy that are more consistent with galactosemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Nitrogen scavenger therapy is used as emergency treatment for patients with hyperammonemia related to urea-cycle defects. This patient has hyperammonemia, but it is not his primary problem, given the other symptoms he has that are not related to urea-cycle defects (including hypoglycemia, congenital cataracts, and coagulopathy). Hyperammonemia is often thought to be a primary symptom of galactosemia, but this is a misconception. Ammonia levels are commonly elevated to between 100 and 300 μg/dL in sick neonates, regardless of the underlying cause of disease, and treating the underlying disease resolves the hyperammonemia. In urea-cycle defects, ammonia levels typically exceed 500 μg/dL.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with classic galactosemia and warrants immediate discontinuation of galactose from the diet. Newborn screening in the United States is highly sensitive for galactosemia and, in most cases, allows for presymptomatic detection. However, this patient was born at home. Only two-thirds of babies born at home receive newborn screening, and those who do often have their screening sent late, when it may be less sensitive and less likely to detect presymptomatic disease.

The hallmark features of classic galactosemia include poor feeding, jaundice, hypoglycemia, coagulopathy, hepatomegaly, and Escherichia coli sepsis. The hyperbilirubinemia in this condition is typically unconjugated at first but then evolves to conjugated within 1 to 2 weeks, as in this case. About one-third of patients have congenital cataracts, and the rest develop them over time if the galactosemia is not treated. Infants with cataracts have leukocoria, an abnormal pupillary reflex that appears white rather than red.

The diagnosis of classic galactosemia is established by detection of an elevated galactose-1-phosphate concentration in erythrocytes, reduced galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) enzyme activity in erythrocytes, and/or biallelic pathogenic variants in GALT. Classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Definitive treatment for galactosemia is the restriction of galactose and, in particular, dairy products, as these are the main source of galactose. Early treatment (within the first week of life) prevents most early symptoms. Even postsymptomatic treatment can reverse early symptoms, although cataracts are only treatable in about two-thirds of cases. In this patient, stopping breast milk and switching to a galactose-free formula, such as any standard soy formula, should reverse most early symptoms and prevent further buildup of galactose.

Late symptoms of galactosemia — which include developmental delay with expressive language delay, fine motor and coordination problems, and primary ovarian insufficiency — can be observed despite proper nutritional intervention and may remain unchanged even with the recommended lifelong galactose-free diet. Calcium, vitamin D, and vitamin K supplementation is recommended to help prevent decreases in bone mineralization.

Key learning point: Neonatal cataracts, hypoglycemia, jaundice, coagulopathy, and sepsis are manifestations of galactosemia.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy is brought in for a well-child visit. His parents’ only concern is that when they try to wean him from night feeds, he becomes completely inconsolable after only 3 to 4 hours and can be calmed only by feeding.
His length is at the 5th percentile, down from the 25th percentile at his last visit, and his weight is at the 25th percentile. His general appearance is notable for remarkably full cheeks, a very protuberant abdomen, and thin extremities. His liver is palpated just above the iliac crest; the spleen is not palpable.
When blood is drawn for laboratory testing, it has a milky white layer on top.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Phosphomannomutase deficiency (congenital disorder of glycosylation, type 1a)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niemann-Pick disease type C causes hepatomegaly but always in association with splenomegaly. It does not cause fasting intolerance or lipemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Prader-Willi syndrome causes truncal obesity with small hands and feet (but normal limbs), usually starting around age 2. Infants with this syndrome are poor eaters and may be unusually thin, but they would not be expected to have organomegaly or lipemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Phosphomannomutase deficiency (congenital disorder of glycosylation, type 1a) may have polymorphic, multiorgan involvement, including hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia and poor growth. Patients with this condition may appear superficially similar to those with GSD-1, as they have abnormal fat distribution with prominent cheeks and may have a prominent abdomen with skinny limbs. However, in phosphomannomutase deficiency, the abdominal protuberance is caused by ascites, not hepatomegaly. In addition, when fat distribution is abnormal, the patient usually has striking nipple inversion and abnormal fat pads above the buttock with sparse buttock fat. Lipemia and hepatomegaly are not associated with this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency causes a primary hypertriglyceridemia with blood lipemia and occasionally borderline hepatomegaly, but it would not cause massive hepatomegaly or fasting intolerance. Furthermore, only one-quarter of affected patients present with symptoms before one year of age.

E) CORRECT:

The combination of hepatomegaly, lipemia, and fasting intolerance is classically associated with glycogen storage disease (GSD) type 1. The hepatomegaly is caused by the accumulation of glycogen in the liver. Associated laboratory abnormalities include elevations in triglycerides, cholesterol, lactic acid, and uric acid. The elevated triglyceride and lipid levels result in the patient having a doll-like face (with prominent cheeks), lipemia (which may be evident as a milky layer on the blood even before testing results are in), and occasionally xanthomatosis related to fatty deposition in the skin. Meanwhile, because affected children are unable to access calories stored as glycogen, their growth slows and their extremities are thin. Subclinical hypoglycemia results in fasting intolerance, which in many cases becomes apparent during sleep training. Although hypoglycemia is the most life-threatening sign of GSD-1, it is rarely the presenting sign because glycogen stores are not maximally used until fasting time exceeds 3 to 4 hours.

GSD-1 is caused by a dysfunction in the enzymes glucose-6-phosphatase and glucose-6-phosphate exchanger, which can be tested in liver tissue. Given that such testing requires an invasive liver biopsy procedure, diagnosis is often achieved through DNA testing. Disease management relies on optimal nutrition to avoid prolonged fasting and includes providing uncooked cornstarch at night as a slow-release source of glucose.

Key learning point: Hepatomegaly, lipemia, and fasting intolerance are cardinal features of glycogen storage disease type 1.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy with Pompe disease presents with failure to thrive, tachycardia, and respiratory distress. His parents report that he has episodes of poor feeding associated with sweating and respiratory distress. He has had no exposure to sick contacts.
On physical examination, he is fussy, tachypneic, and very hypotonic when held. He has a respiratory rate of 60 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 170 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 70/40 mm Hg. Physical examination is notable for ptosis and macroglossia. Cardiac examination reveals a short systolic murmur and a gallop. Rales are heard over both lung bases with scattered wheezes. Abdominal examination shows mild hepatomegaly. Musculoskeletal and neurologic examination is notable for head lag, calf pseudohypertrophy, and profound generalized hypotonia. The patient’s legs are in the frog-leg position, and deep-tendon reflexes are diminished.
Which one of the following additional clinical features would most likely be observed in this infant?

choices.text: Muscle pain with associated urine discoloration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ketotic hypoglycemia is not a feature of Pompe disease. Instead, it occurs in conditions associated with hepatic forms of GSD, such as types 3a, 3b, 6, and 9. Of note, GSD type 3a may be associated with muscle weakness, cardiac hypertrophy without evidence of heart failure, and CK elevations. However, the typical age of onset for GSD 3a is not until later in childhood.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe muscle pain or cramping with discoloration of the urine is characteristic of rhabdomyolysis, which is induced by dynamic exercise in patients with other types of glycogen storage disease, such as GSD type 5 (McArdle disease) and type 7 (Tarui disease). Rhabdomyolysis usually does not occur in Pompe disease, which is a static myopathy associated with mild to moderate elevations in creatine kinase (CK).

C) INCORRECT:

Acrodermatitis enteropathica occurs in neonates with disorders of biotin metabolism, severe zinc deficiency, and some organic acidemias. However, there is no connection specifically between acrodermatitis enteropathica and Pompe disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Coarse facial features occur with other lysosomal storage disorders, such as mucopolysaccharidosis and mucolipidosis, but are not seen with Pompe disease.

E) CORRECT:

Pompe disease is a rare, progressive muscular disease caused by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes due to a deficiency of the acid alpha-glucosidase (GAA) enzyme. Sometimes referred to as glycogen storage disease (GSD) type 2, Pompe disease can be categorized as either infantile or late onset depending on the age of onset, extent of cardiac involvement, and rate of disease progression.

• In infantile-onset Pompe disease, patients typically present in the first few months of life with failure to thrive, severe skeletal muscle weakness, motor developmental delay, frequent respiratory infections, and biventricular hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (with or without cardiac dysfunction). The disease progresses rapidly and can be fatal by 12 months without enzyme-replacement therapy.
• In late-onset Pompe disease, patients typically present with proximal muscle weakness and respiratory dysfunction without cardiac hypertrophy. Diagnosis may occur during infancy or much later, and the disease tends to progress more slowly.

Key learning point: Children with infantile-onset Pompe disease develop early-onset hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with resultant symptoms of neonatal heart failure (tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding).

questions.text: A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and weakness. His mother reports that he has difficulty feeding. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 3rd percentile for weight. Physical examination shows an enlarged tongue. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum glucose is 95 mg/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows cardiomegaly. The patient most likely has a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase causes Pompe disease. Without this enzyme, the conversion of glycogen to glucose in the lysosome cannot be completed and glycogen buildup becomes toxic to numerous cells, predominantly skeletal and cardiac muscle cells. Pompe disease does not present with hypoglycemia because glycolysis and gluconeogenesis do not depend on lysosomal glycogenolysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Myophosphorylase deficiency causes McArdle disease, which can cause fatigue and weakness. However, the onset is usually during adolescence or early adulthood. Macroglossia and features of heart failure would not occur because McArdle disease only affects skeletal muscles.

C) INCORRECT:

Iduronate sulfatase deficiency causes Hunter syndrome, which would almost exclusively affect males (X-linked recessive disorder). Failure to thrive, macroglossia, and heart failure (due to valvular heart disease) can also occur with severe forms of Hunter syndrome. However, the clinical features of Hunter disease typically do not manifest before the first year of life.

D) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase causes von Gierke disease, which can present with failure to thrive, easy fatiguability, and heart failure during infancy. However, hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly would be expected, and macroglossia would not occur.

This patient's liver does not meet the definition of hepatomegaly since the liver is physiologically palpable 1–2 cm below the costal margin in infants and toddlers.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta-glucocerebrosidase deficiency causes Gaucher disease, which can cause failure to thrive during infancy. However, other manifestations such as skeletal abnormalities (e.g., osteoporosis, aseptic necrosis of the femoral head, painful bone crises), hepatosplenomegaly, and/or pancytopenia (bleeding, recurrent infections) would also be expected. Neurological disease occurs in less common forms of Gaucher disease (type 2 and 3) but presents as progressive spasticity (not hypotonia). Cardiac involvement in Gaucher disease is uncommon.

F) INCORRECT:

Alpha-galactosidase deficiency causes Fabry disease, which would almost exclusively affect males (X-linked recessive disorder) and cause failure to thrive. However, the onset of symptoms is usually during childhood or adolescence, and patients typically present with angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, recurrent abdominal pain, corneal clouding, tinnitus, hearing loss, and/or acral paresthesias. Heart failure is less common and typically a late manifestation. Macroglossia would not be expected.
questions.hint: This child's failure to thrive, generalized hypotonia, signs of heart failure due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (e.g., pulmonary edema, cardiomegaly), macroglossia, and normal serum glucose suggest Pompe disease.
